context: For determining the PCm/a and PCcol/a, pre-weighed Hewlett-Packard headspace vials (Hewlett-Packard Co., Palo Alto, CA) with an average measured volume (water displacement) of 12.00±0.01 (SE) containing either 1.0 ml complete cell culture medium or 0.5–0.6 g freshly excised rat tail tendons (collagen source; kindly provided by Carol Garrett, Wright-Patterson AFB, OH) were sealed with aluminum crimp seals containing a Teflon-coated rubber septum, and incubated at 37°C for 30 min on a vortex evaporator to equilibrate. A Tedlar gas sample bag (SKC Inc., Eighty Four, PA) containing 5000 ppm m-xylene was prepared and allowed to equilibrate. Following venting of the vials to relieve pressure, a designated amount of headspace was removed using a Hamilton gastight glass syringe (Hamilton Company, Reno, NV) and replaced with a corresponding volume from the Tedlar sample bag to provide 125, 250, or 375 ppm m-xylene in the vials. Following incubation at 37°C for 4 h on a vortex evaporator, the m-xylene concentration in the headspace of each vial was analyzed using a Hewlett-Packard 5890 Series II Gas Chromatograph containing a J&W Scientific DB-5 column (J&W Scientific Inc., Folsom, CA), and EZChrom Elite software (Scientific Software, Inc., Pleasanton, CA). Reference vials without medium and containing 125, 250, or 375 ppm m-xylene were used as controls, while medium only vials without m-xylene were used as blanks. To confirm equilibration was established by 4 h, additional PCm/a were measured at 0.25, 1, 2, and 4 h (n=3 per time point) using 250 ppm.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 1,3-xylene is mentioned as part of an experimental setup involving the equilibration of volatile organic compounds in sealed vials under specific conditions, including pressure changes. However, the relationship between 1,3-xylene and pressure as a physical agent is not explicitly discussed or analyzed, indicating a lack of direct interaction or significance in the study.
